A **bugle** is a type of [musical instrument](/wiki/Musical_instrument "Musical instrument") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper").

The bugle is the only non-[magical](/wiki/Magical_tool "Magical tool") [tonal instrument](/wiki/Tonal_instrument "Tonal instrument") that lacks a magical equivalent.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.2 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

[Elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") and [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") have a 1⁄6 chance of starting the game with a bugle.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Yendorian Army](/wiki/Yendorian_Army "Yendorian Army") sergeants, lieutenants, and captains have a 1⁄3 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a bugle.

## Description

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a bugle will allow you to play it. Improvising can awaken or scare nearby monsters, as with a [tooled horn](/wiki/Tooled_horn "Tooled horn")[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) - however, it will also awaken, anger, and unparalyze all soldiers and [watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") on the level.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) Improvising abuses your [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom").[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Yendorian Army fighters with bugles are capable of using them to the same effect, and will do so if there is another soldier [sleeping](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") or otherwise immobile in a 7×7 square around them, awakening other monsters and potentially scaring any [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") as well.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [this commit](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/141a7915d6d4034353b6910515dc50e240f7f5b3), bugles work against fewer monsters, and some are completely immune.

## Strategy

A bugle can be a good substitute for a tooled horn - they are lighter and have a good chance of scaring most monsters outside of the Yendorian Army. However, they cannot be safely used in [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") unless you can neutralize or pacify the watch, and it is best to look for [barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") before using your bugle on later levels, including the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"). Bugles are also a reason to tread carefully when clearing out any barracks, as one of the higher-ranked fighters may carry one and will wake up their sleeping comrades the first chance they get, spoiling any sleep- or [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth")-based approach you were employing at that point.

Bugles are very useful tools for the late game on, since you are likely to obtain one that you can play the [passtune](/wiki/Passtune "Passtune") with before you reach the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"); they can also keep [hostile priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") from surrounding you in the [Sanctum](/wiki/Sanctum "Sanctum"), and drive away [air elementals](/wiki/Air_elemental "Air elemental") on the [Plane of Air](/wiki/Plane_of_Air "Plane of Air").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As a consequence of the above commit, priests and Angels are no longer scared by bugles.

## History

The bugle first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). Its ability to scare monsters was introduced in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"); variants based on previous versions are likely to not include this feature.

## Messages

- You extract a loud noise from \<your bugle>.

  You applied a bugle and improvised.

- You extract a strange sound from the bugle!

  You applied a bugle and played a specific melody with it.

- You blow into the bugle.

  As above, while [deaf](/wiki/Deaf "Deaf").

- You hear a bugle playing reveille!

  A soldier played a bugle.

* \<The soldier> is now ready for battle!

  One or more soldiers were awakened, unparalyzed and made hostile.

* You hear the rattle of battle gear being readied.

  As above while outside your range of vision.

## Variants

Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions may not add the bugle's scaring properties introduced in later versions.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") [Troubadours](/wiki/Troubadour "Troubadour") have a 1⁄2 chance of their starting tonal instrument being a bugle.

The bugle is the preferred instrument for playing Rally, Charge and Inspire Courage via the Troubadour's musicalize spell [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), and is an alternate instrument for playing Disruption.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), orcish Bards have a 1⁄2 chance of starting with a bugle, as in dNetHack.

The bugle is the preferred instrument for playing Inspire Courage via the musicalize spell skill.

## Encyclopedia entry

'I read you by your bugle horn  
And by your palfrey good,  
I read you for a Ranger sworn  
To keep the King's green-wood.'  
'A Ranger, Lady, winds his horn,  
And 'tis at peep of light;  
His blast is heard at merry morn,  
And mine at dead of night.'

\[ Brignall Banks, by Sir Walter Scott ]
